I had him taken about half-past eleven o'clock that night - he said he knew nothing of it, and had no gold or any money about him - I am sure of that; he was searched in my presence, and 1l. 2s. 6d. in silver, and some halfpence were found on him.

REBECCA DARTSSE
. I was working at the prosecutor's on the 6th of January - I saw the prisoner there about two o'clock; he asked me for a shirt - I aired it, and gave it him; he went up stairs to put it on, and brought down his dirty one.

GEORGE SMITH
. I am tapster to the prosecutor. On Sunday, the 6th of January, I saw the prisoner with his shirt on his hand, going towards the stairs; he came down again in ten minutes or a quarter of an hour - there had been several persons there on the Saturday night, and there were five or six persons in the house on Sunday.

CHARLES BANNISTER
. I am a servant out of place. On the 6th of January I was at the Tavistock Arms public-house, Tavistock-place, Brunswick-square, between six and seven o'clock in the evening; the prisoner came in and called for a quartern of gin - I knew him before, and had part of it; he paid for it with a half-sovereign; he had it in a little bag - he put his fingers into the bag, and said he was not without money, and I saw, I thought, ten or twelve sovereigns in it.

HENRY BUTT
. I am pot-boy at the Hand and Chair public-house, Colonade. The prisoner came there about seven o'clock, and had some refreshment; I saw him open a little bag with six or seven sovereings in it.

RICHARD DAVIS
. I was constable of the night; the prisoner was brought to the watch-house about half-past eleven o'clock on the 6th of January; I found on him 23s. in silver, and 1s. 2d. in copper. He said he lodged in Coram-street.
The prisoner put in a written Defence, denying the charge.
NOT GUILTY .
First London Jury - before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

479.
WALTER WEBB
was indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of December , 250lbs, weight of cork, value 5l. 10s. , the goods of
William Peter McAndrews
.

WILLIAM PETER McANDREWS. I am a fruit-merchant , in partnership with my brother, and live in London-street. I employed the prisoner to discharge, unload, and warehouse a quantity of cork, which I had purchased; the cork in question was in a cellar in George-lane
; the whole delivery was complete on Saturday, the 8th of December, and we discharged the prisoner that evening; he had superintended the delivery, and had men under him; his accounts were all settled that evening; and on the Monday I gave him in charge, on suspicion of stealing cork from George-lane; he had nothing to do with cork after the 8th.
Cross-examined. Q. When did you speak to him about this? A. On the Tuesday; he came to my house with oranges - I gave him in charge.

ALFRED WALKER
. I live with my parents, in George-lane, and work at a jewellers, in Great Queen-street; the prosecutor's cellar is under our house. On Monday, the 10th of December, about a quarter to nine o'clock, the prisoner came and asked for a light; my brother was at the door with me; he brought a truck, went into the cellar, and took away three bundles of cork on the truck; he had been there before, about cork; the cellar was not locked; my father has the care of it; the door is inside the house.

Cross-examined by MR. BODKIN. Q. Does not your father keep the key? A. There is no lock; it is bolted; we have two lodgers - I had never seen him there before myself; he had a fustain coat on, I believe. When I was at the Mansion-house, I was desired to look among the prisoners for the man, and it was five minutes before I fixed on him - I passed him several times; my brother pointed him out, and then I knew him.
COURT. Q. Can you now say, you are sure he is the man? A. Yes - I always said so.

WILLIAM WALKER
. I am nine years old, and live with my father in George-lane. On Monday, the 10th of December, a man came with a truck, and took away three bundles of cork; the prisoner is that man, he asked me for a light, and I gave it to him.
Cross-examined. Q. How often had you seen him before? A. On the Friday and Saturday; he had a fustian jacket on; my brother was with me.

DAVID WRIGHT
. I am a ship-agent, and live in Thames-street. I had a truck in my care on the 10th of December; it was missing that morning, from about nine till near twelve o'clock - I live about a quarter of a mile from George-lane. I know nothing of the prisoner.

JOHN HALL
. I am a fruit-cooper. On Monday morning, the 10th of December, I saw the prisoner with a truck, and three bundles of cork in it, going up Pudding-lane, close to George-lane, it was about nine o'clock in the morning.
Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known him? A. Two years.

JOSEPH ROME
. I live in George-lane. On Monday, the 10th of December, I heard a noise, and saw a truck opposite No. 3 - the prisoner brought out three bundles of cork singly - I believe him to be the man, but will not swear to him.

JOHN BAYLEY
. I am an officer, and took him in charge.
Prisoner's Defence. I know myself innocent.
Three witnesses gave the prisoner a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Confined Six Months .

480.
PETER CRAWLEY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of December , 2 boots, value 16s. , the goods of
Anthony Smith Johnson
.

JOSEPH SOUTHEY
. I am shopman to Anthony Smith Johnson, of Aldersgate-street
. About six o'clock in the evening of the 26th of December, I was under the windowboard, and could not be seen; the prisoner came into the shop, looked round for about a minute, took a pair of boots, and walked away; I cried Stop thief! twice, and pursued him; he dropped them at the corner of Long-lane, crossed over, and turned round to walk towards Aldersgate-street again, and was taken - I never lost sight of him.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JOHN BUCE
. I am a patrol. I heard the alarm, and took the prisoner.
ANTHONY SMITH JOHNSON. I keep this shop, and was in the parlour at the time.

Prisoner's Defence. I had just left my lodgings, and at the top of Long-lane I crossed the road; Southey came up, and said I had stolen the boots; a gentleman and lady gave me their address, and said they would prove I was not the man - they were here last night, and are gone into the country.
ANTHONY SMITH JOHNSON. A lady and gentleman came into the shop, and left their card with the prisoner.

JOSEPH SOUTHEY
. I did not hear them say the prisoner was not the man.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Six Weeks .
Fifth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

481.
ELIZA PHILLIPS
was indicted for a
burglary in the dwelling-house of
Maria Fitzgibbon
, about eleven o'clock on the night of the 13th of December , with intent to steal, and stealing therein 2 sheets, value 5s., the goods of
Thomas Parker
; and 6 gowns, value 20s.; 2 shawls, value 10s.; 4 petticoats, value 12s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 2s.; 1 shift, value 2s.; 1 night-gown, value 1s.; 1 veil, value 2s., and 5 collars, value 1s. , the goods of the said Maria Fitzgibbon.

MARIA FITGIBBON. I am single , and lodged in a back garret, in New-street, St. Giles'
. I am a servant , out of place; the landlord did not live in the house - his name is Parker. I went out at eleven o'clock at night of the 13th of December, on business, leaving my key with Mrs. Parker; I returned at twelve o'clock - the street door is kept on the latch - I found the hasp of my lock had been drawn out, but the landlord had put it on again; I went in, and missed the articles stated in the indictment. I knew the prisoner - she had visited me once in that room; I sometimes do needle-work, and when I cannot get it, I sometimes get my living in the street, I am sorry to say.

THOMAS PARKER. I let this house out in separate lodgings, and live next door; Fitzgibbon left her key with my wife, about eleven o'clock, and in about an hour Driscoll came in, in his shirt, and gave an alarm; I took a candle, went up stairs at this house, to the back garret, and saw the prisoner on the landing-place, and all these articles strewed about - she had no business there - she had no property in her possession; she called to me directly I got up, and begged me to forgive her, and let her go; I said she had broken into the room and stolen the things, and I could not let her go - I found an iron pin, about six steps from the room-door - the staple appeared to have been drawn out by that pin; no other women lodge there.

DENNIS DRISCOLL
. I am a labourer, and lodge at this house - I was at home at eleven o'clock at night - I went to bed about eleven, and in about half an hour heard a noise, like the breaking open of the staple of a door - I listened, then went up in the dark, and found the prisoner there; all the things laid about - I called for a light, and went for the landlord; the things were not packed up - I held her till the light came - I know nothing about the iron pin.

JAMES DOODY
. I am an officer. I was sent for to the house. I went up, and took the prisoner into custody - I found the property on the landing, and some part inside the door.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. I have known her two years - she is a prostitute, like myself - we once lived together; I only went up to see if she was at home - the man came up, and said I came to rob the house.
MARIA FILZGIBBON. We never lived together. I have walked with her, and we have drank together; I was in service five weeks ago, for about half a year.
NOT GUILTY .

482.
HENRY HEATH
and
HENRY PARSONS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of January , 18 penny-pieces, and 21 halfpence , the monies of
William Ashby
.

HEATH
pleaded GUILTY .
Fined One Shilling and Discharged.

PARSONS
pleaded GUILTY .

Confined Two Months , and
Whipped .
